journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Determination of representative dimension parameter values of Korean knee joints for knee joint implant design

article-meta.aff: 1Catholic Institute for Applied Anatomy, The Catholic University of Korea, Republic of Korea
2School of Mechanical Systems Engineering, Chonnam National University, Republic of Korea
3Research Institute for Applied Mechanics, Kyushu University, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Insu Jeon, School of Mechanical Systems Engineering, Chonnam National University, 300 Yongbong-dong, Buk-gu, Gwangju, 500-757, Republic of Korea. Email: i_jeon@chonnam.ac.kr

abstract.p: Knee joint implants developed by western companies have been imported to Korea and used for Korean patients. However, many clinical problems occur in knee joints of Korean patients after total knee joint replacement owing to the geometric mismatch between the western implants and Korean knee joint structures. To solve these problems, a method to determine the representative dimension parameter values of Korean knee joints is introduced to aid in the design of knee joint implants appropriate for Korean patients. Measurements of the dimension parameters of 88 male Korean knee joint subjects were carried out. The distribution of the subjects versus each measured parameter value was investigated. The measured dimension parameter values of each parameter were grouped by suitable intervals called the “size group,” and average values of the size groups were calculated. The knee joint subjects were grouped as the “patient group” based on “size group numbers” of each parameter. From the iterative calculations to decrease the errors between the average dimension parameter values of each “patient group” and the dimension parameter values of the subjects, the average dimension parameter values that give less than the error criterion were determined to be the representative dimension parameter values for designing knee joint implants for Korean patients.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The knee is the largest joint in the human body and allows body movements for daily activity. It is a complex combination of biological components including the femur, tibia, patella, cartilage, meniscus, ligaments, muscles, and tendons.1 The most common disease that destroys knee joint function is arthritis. Arthritis is an inflammation of the joint that can result in extreme pain, swelling, stiffness, and limited movement.2–5 The short-term solutions for these symptoms are physical therapy, medications, and intra-articular treatment. However, in many cases, the only long-term remedy is surgery.6–10

Total knee replacement (TKR) is a surgical operation in which the knee joint is replaced with an artificial implant to restore damaged knee function. It is well known that the most critical phase of TKR is the choice of the size, position, and orientation of the knee joint prosthesis components, considering the anatomical features of the patient’s lower limb. A correct choice of the prosthesis improves the resulting joint function and duration for daily use.11–14 Therefore, geometric suitability between a human knee joint and the knee joint implant is one of the most crucial factors for a successful outcome.

Although numerous studies have been undertaken for the design of knee joint implants,15–19 most of them were carried out for western populations by western researchers. Based on these results, many western medical companies have developed knee joint implants. On the other hand, in the Korean medical community, knee joint implants developed by western companies have been imported and directly used for Korean patients because Korea is a latecomer to the implant industry. The anatomical knee joint structures of Koreans are significantly different from those of western populations.20 Therefore, many clinical problems occur in Korean patients’ knee joints after TKA using imported knee joint implants.

The purpose of this research is to determine the representative dimension parameter values (DPVs) of Korean knee joints for designing knee joint implants for Korean patients. For this purpose, an anthropometric study of the dimension parameters of Korean knee joint subjects was carried out, and the distribution of these numbers versus each measured parameter value was investigated. The measured dimension values of each parameter were grouped by suitable intervals as the “size group” and the average values were calculated. Then, the knee joint subjects were grouped as the “patient group” based on size group numbers of each parameter. From iterative calculations to decrease the errors between the average DPVs of each patient group and the DPVs of each subject, the average dimension values that give less than the error criterion were determined to be representative DPVs.

sec.title: Patients and measurements
sec.p: This study was performed using 88 knee joint subjects obtained from 44 Korean male cadavers without gross congenital anomaly or deformity. The average age was 50.3 years (from 21 to 60 years old). The average height was 166 cm and the average tibial length was 33.0 cm.

X-ray computed tomography (CT) images were taken from every knee joint subject. Using these images, each knee joint was three-dimensionally reconstructed using the commercial software MIMICS (v10.1, Materialise, Belgium). The reconstructed models were used to measure the DPVs of each knee joint using digital calipers. Six dimension parameters were selected from the resected distal femur, see Figure 1(a) and (b)): CML (mediolateral length), PWL (width of lateral posterior condyle), PHL (height of lateral posterior condyle), PWM (width of medial posterior condyle), PHM (height of medial posterior condyle) and CAP (anteroposterior length). These parameters are directly related to geometric sizes of the femoral part of a knee joint implant (see Figure 1(c) and (d)).

caption.p: Dimension parameters. (a) and (b) resected distal femur model, and (c) and (d) related geometric sizes of the femoral part of a knee joint implant.

CAP: anteroposterior length; CML: mediolateral length; PHL: height of lateral posterior condyle; PWL: width of lateral posterior condyle; PHM: height of medial posterior condyle; PWM: width of medial posterior condyle.

sec.title: Determination of representative DPVs
sec.p: The method to determine the representative DPVs of Korean knee joints is shown in Figure 2. First, measurements of the six dimension parameters from the Korean knee joint subjects were carried out. The distribution of the subjects versus each measured parameter value was investigated (see Figure 3(a)–(f)). Based on the distribution, the “size groups” were determined considering suitable intervals of each parameter value. The “size group number” was assigned in order from the group that includes the smallest value of each dimension parameter. Also, the average value of the dimension parameters of each size group was calculated. Each “patient group” and “patient group number” was decided by the same “size group number” of each dimension parameter (see Figure 4).

caption.p: Flow diagram for deciding representative geometric sizes of knee joint implants.

Distributions of the number of subjects versus the values of (a) CML: mediolateral length; (b) PWL: width of lateral posterior condyle; (c) PHL: height of lateral posterior condyle; (d) PWM: width of medial posterior condyle; (e) PHM: height of medial posterior condyle; and (f) CAP: anteroposterior length.
Determination of patient groups from size groups.
CML: mediolateral length; PWL: width of lateral posterior condyle; CAP: anteroposterior length.

sec.p: To determine the “patient group” and “patient group number” of a subject, the “size group” and “size group number” of each parameter of a subject was considered. A subject has six DPVs. For those six parameter values, a size group of each parameter was assigned to a subject. Thus, a subject has six “size groups” and “size group numbers”. The “patient group” and “patient group number” of a subject was decided as the majority “size group numbers” of the major three parameters that were CML, PWL, and CAP.

After comparison between the average DPVs of each size group in the patient group of a subject and the DPVs of the subject, average dimension values with less than the error criterion (10% error in this study) were selected as representative DPVs for designing the femoral part of Korean knee joint implants (see Figure 1(c) and (d)).

This method should be applied, not only to male and female knee joints, but also to design the femur or tibia parts of the implants separately. In this research, we obtained representative DPVs for the design of the femoral part of Korean male knee joint implants. This is the key component in the flexion range of an artificial knee, and it requires great care in design. The other cases were not considered in this research because the same procedure could be applied to obtain the representative DPVs.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Distributions of the subjects versus the values of six dimension parameters (CML, PWL, PHL, PWM, PHM, CAP) are shown in Figure 3(a)–(f). Based on these distributions, the values of each dimension parameter were divided, and the size groups for each parameter in a knee joint were determined. The number of size groups in a dimension parameter was determined by the number of divided intervals. For determination of the intervals of all dimension parameters, the number of intervals of the dimension parameter CML was regarded as the criterion. This is because CML is the most significant parameter, which is related to adequate cover of the femoral part implant on the resected bone surface,13,21 and affects smooth tracking of the patellar component with the implant during flexion.22 From the distribution of the number of subjects of the CML shown in Figure 3(a), nine divided intervals (i.e. nine size groups) were determined and are shown in Table 1. The remaining dimension parameters were also divided into nine size groups, respectively, following those of the CML parameter (see Table 1).

caption.p: Divided intervals of each dimension parameter (mm).

fn.p: CML: mediolateral length, PWL: width of lateral posterior condyle, PHL: height of lateral posterior condylar, PWM: width of medial posterior condyle, PHM: height of medial posterior condylar, CAP: anteroposterior length.

Since the size groups and the group number of each parameter, and their average DPVs, were determined, the “patient group” and “patient group number” of a subject could be determined. Table 3 shows the determined patient groups and their group numbers. In the table, we note that two patient groups have no subjects. Therefore, only seven patient groups are available in this study.

sec.p: Once the patient group number of a subject was determined, only one size group number for all parameters was assigned to the subject, which was the same number as the patient group number. For example, if a subject has been assigned to patient group 1, size group 1 of all six parameters are assigned for the subject again, even though the subject has been assigned different first size group numbers for each parameter (see Figure 4). Therefore, the errors between the average DPVs of a newly assigned size group owing to the determined patient group, and the actual DPVs of the subject in the same patient group, must be evaluated. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: To obtain representative DPVs for knee joint implants appropriate for Korean patients, an anthropometric study of Korean knee joints was performed. The DPVs of resected distal femurs of 88 knee joints from 44 Korean male cadavers were measured. Based on the measured data, the distributions of the numbers of the subject versus measured DPVs were investigated, and the size groups were determined from a suitable division of the measured DPVs. The average DPVs of each size group were calculated, and their validity was confirmed after calculating the errors between each average DPV in each size group and the DPVs of every subject in the same size group.

The patient group was decided based on the size group numbers of major dimension parameters of knee joint subjects. We performed iterative calculations to decrease the errors between the average DPVs of each patient group and the DPVs of the subjects. The average DPVs that gave less than 10% error were selected as representative DPVs for designing the femoral part of knee joint implants appropriate for Korean patients.

From the results, nine size groups of six parameters were decided upon. Seven available patient groups and seven sets of each representative DPV were obtained. The method used in this study could also be applied to the tibia and to female knee joint implants. Our results can be used for the design and fabrication of knee joint implants.

fn.p: This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) Grant (NRF-2011-616-D00004).

ack.p: The authors thank the Korea Institute of Science and Technology Information (KISTI) for providing Korean knee joint data.
